COMMEMORATION DAY EXERCISES TO BE HELD
TOMORROW
The Honorable Calvin Coolidge to Be
Principle Speaker. Exercises to
Begin at Eleven O'Clock.

The twenty-second of February
is one of the most important days
in the year for the Johns Hopkins
University. There will be observed
in the Lyric Theatre tomorrow the
forty-sixth anniversary of the opening of our Alma Mater. President
Goodnow has been fortunate enough to obtain, to make the principle address, the Honorable Calvin
Coolidge, L. L. D., Vice-President
of the United States. The program
for the Commemoration Day exercises is as follows:
The trustees and faculty will assemble at 10:30 o'clock in the hall
over the main lobby.
The official guests are invited to
join the academic procession in the
same place at 10:30.
The Alumni will assemble at
10.30 in the lower hall on Maryland Avenue, whence they will proceed to reserved seats in the auditorium.
The students will meet at 10.15
in the same room and will proceed,
under the direction of the marshals
to seats reserved for them. The
procession will enter the auditorium
ot a quarter before eleven.
Boxes and the first floor will be
reserved until after the procession
has entered, when the remaining
seats will be thrown open to the
o
public.
The
will begin punctually at eleven o'clock, and will
close probably before one. A number of degrees will be given. Besides those of Doctor of Laws,
there will be conferred six degrees
of Doctor of Philosophy, one degree of Doctor of Science and Hygiene, one degree of Doctor of
Medicine, one degree of Bachelor
o f Civil Engineering, two degrees
of Bachelor of Arts.
This is the one time in the year
when the student body must make
a splendid showing. It is the wish
of President Goodnow that every
man attend who possibly can. The
exercises are not only impressive
and affective, but interesting as
well. It is highly desirable that
every, man in the University be
there not only to do homage to his
Alma Mater, but for his own benefit and entertainment.
TEA DANCE HELD SATURDAY

Last Saturday afternoon at four
o'clock, under the, auspices of the
Cotillon Board, the first of a series
of tea dances was held in the C. E.
Hall. The dance was particularly
enjoyable and was all the more appreciated because it was the first
afternoon affair since the close of
the football season. The University Jazz Band furnished the music
and it was undoubtedly at its best.
The girls of Baltimore appeared
ell represented, with sub-debs
chiefly in evidence.
The success of this dance is unquestionable and similar affairs
will be held every other week from
now on. March 4 and 18, and
April 4 and 8 are the dates selected for succeeding ones.

HOPKINS SWIMMERS OUTCLASSED BY COLUMBIA
New Yorkers Win Every Event. Coady
Best for Black and Blue.

The Johns Hopkins tankmen
met a tartar in Columbia University
at New York last Saturday evening
and were swamped to the tune of
44 to 9. The Blue and White team
captured every first place and garnered in majority of second and
thirds as well. Polk, of Columbia,
was the star of the meet, winning
first place in both the 50-yard and
For Hopkins
220-yard races.
Coady scored the largest number
of points by taking second in the
220 and third in the fancy diving,
The New Yorkers started the
works by out-classing the visitors
in the 260-yard relay, covering the
distance in the fast time of 1 minlite 48 seconds. The second event,
the fancy diving, was won by Balbach, who gave an exhibition
worthy of his reputation as one of
the best fancy divers in the East.
The 50, 100 and 220-yard races
were won in easy fashion by the
Blue and White tankmen, as also
was the plunge for distance.

COMMEMORATION DAY EXERCISES TO BE HELD
TOMORROW
The Honorable Calvin Coolidge to Be
Principle Speaker. Exercises to
Begin at Eleven O'Clock.

The twenty-second of February
is one of the most important days
in the year for the Johns Hopkins
University. There will be observed
in the Lyric Theatre tomorrow the
forty-sixth anniversary of the opening of our Alma Mater. President
Goodnow has been fortunate enough to obtain, to make the principle address, the Honorable Calvin
Coolidge, L. L. D., Vice-President
of the United States. The program
for the Commemoration Day exercises is as follows:
The trustees and faculty will assemble at 10:30 o'clock in the hall
over the main lobby.
The official guests are invited to
join the academic procession in the
same place at 10:30.
The Alumni will assemble at
10.30 in the lower hall on Maryland Avenue, whence they will proceed to reserved seats in the auditorium.
The students will meet at 10.15
in the same room and will proceed,
under the direction of the marshals
to seats reserved for them. The
procession will enter the auditorium
ot a quarter before eleven.
Boxes and the first floor will be
reserved until after the procession
has entered, when the remaining
seats will be thrown open to the
o
public.
The
will begin punctually at eleven o'clock, and will
close probably before one. A number of degrees will be given. Besides those of Doctor of Laws,
there will be conferred six degrees
of Doctor of Philosophy, one degree of Doctor of Science and Hygiene, one degree of Doctor of
Medicine, one degree of Bachelor
o f Civil Engineering, two degrees
of Bachelor of Arts.
This is the one time in the year
when the student body must make
a splendid showing. It is the wish
of President Goodnow that every
man attend who possibly can. The
exercises are not only impressive
and affective, but interesting as
well. It is highly desirable that
every, man in the University be
there not only to do homage to his
Alma Mater, but for his own benefit and entertainment.
TEA DANCE HELD SATURDAY

Last Saturday afternoon at four
o'clock, under the, auspices of the
Cotillon Board, the first of a series
of tea dances was held in the C. E.
Hall. The dance was particularly
enjoyable and was all the more appreciated because it was the first
afternoon affair since the close of
the football season. The University Jazz Band furnished the music
and it was undoubtedly at its best.
The girls of Baltimore appeared
ell represented, with sub-debs
chiefly in evidence.
The success of this dance is unquestionable and similar affairs
will be held every other week from
now on. March 4 and 18, and
April 4 and 8 are the dates selected for succeeding ones.

HOPKINS SWIMMERS OUTCLASSED BY COLUMBIA
New Yorkers Win Every Event. Coady
Best for Black and Blue.

The Johns Hopkins tankmen
met a tartar in Columbia University
at New York last Saturday evening
and were swamped to the tune of
44 to 9. The Blue and White team
captured every first place and garnered in majority of second and
thirds as well. Polk, of Columbia,
was the star of the meet, winning
first place in both the 50-yard and
For Hopkins
220-yard races.
Coady scored the largest number
of points by taking second in the
220 and third in the fancy diving,
The New Yorkers started the
works by out-classing the visitors
in the 260-yard relay, covering the
distance in the fast time of 1 minlite 48 seconds. The second event,
the fancy diving, was won by Balbach, who gave an exhibition
worthy of his reputation as one of
the best fancy divers in the East.
The 50, 100 and 220-yard races
were won in easy fashion by the
Blue and White tankmen, as also
was the plunge for distance.

JUNIOR PROM GREAT SUCCESS

The Junior Prom, held last Friday evening in the Civil Engineering Hall, was a credit both to the
Class of 1923 and to the University
as well. The dance, which started
at nine-fifteen with about twenty
couples present, ended at one
o'clock with about sixty couples
and thirty stags. Dr. and Mrs.
Charles K. Swartz were the only
chaperones
who were present, but
